title: I have about 80,000 in credit card debt that I cannot pay off and want to do chapter 7, but I am married.
question: All this debt is mine, My wife owns all the assets (2 homes) which I quit claimed when she bought them. If I do a bankruptcy myself, are her assets in danger? Would the situation be better if we were divorced?
answers:
Unfortunately, a response to your question requires additional information in order to provide you with a proper answer. However assuming the following assumptions are accurate (1) No prenuptial agreement was executed prior to the marriage (California is a Community Property State); (2) the Credit Card Debt was incurred during the marriage and "Community" benefited from the credit card purchases (extreme example of non-community debt could be that you took the $80K and bet it all on red in Vegas and lost); and (3) the homes were purchased during the marriage with community property funds (income and assets acquired post marriage used to purchase homes) and were not a gift or inheritance to your wife.

All community assets must be listed in a bankruptcy filing, even if both spouses do not file the case. Just because your wife is the only name on title to the property does not mean that the homes are not community property assets. Additionally a divorce now, would not change the status of property acquired prior to a divorce. If it was community property, remains community property until divided by the Family Law Court. Even when there is a divorce, if one of the spouses receives a greater amount of the community assets while the other spouse is left with nothing, the Trustee can challenge the division as a fraudulent transfer.

With that said, just because you are married and may have community property (two houses and other personal property), doesn't mean that you are not eligible for chapter 7 bankruptcy relief or that Trustee would be interested in selling the assets. For instance, if the loans encumbering the homes are greater than the value of the homes, it is unlikely that a Trustee appointed to the case would be interested in the homes anyway.

Best advise - speak with a competent bankruptcy attorney who can guide you through the common pitfalls of a Chapter 7 filing, to protect your assets and make sure your bankruptcy disclosures are proper and accurate. There is nothing worse than seeing an individual lose an asset or have their discharge denied because of misunderstanding or misconceptions of the law.

A good place to start would be the CA state bar website www.cabar.org and look for an attorney who is a certified bankruptcy specialist in your area.

The only assets that would be in danger are community property, ie., assets that were acquired during the marriage. Your quitclaims may or may not have any effect; but we don't have enough information to say much more. Do you live in one of the homes, is there equity in the other, were there separate property funds used to acquire them, etc? And don't forget, her income is also a factor in determining if you qualify for Ch7.

In general, one spouse can file a bankruptcy. That's the least of the issues here in all likelihood. This is a relatively complicated situation and creates questions regarding community interests, timing of the transfers relative to bankruptcy, etc. You need an experienced bankruptcy lawyer in your area. I strongly suggest you do not attempt to file this yourself.
